Award.AwardTitle: Along-shelf Transport and Cross-shelf Exchange Driven by Surface Waves on the Inner Continental Shelf
Award.AbstractNarration:
Exchange across the inner shelf influences the distribution of nutrients, harmful algal blooms, pollutants, larvae and sediment. It is not yet fully understood how surface waves influence this exchange. Recent advances have been made in the numerical modeling of wave-current interactions, but so far these modeling studies have focused on the surf zone. This study will extend these modeling capabilities to the inner shelf by testing model results in the context of laboratory and field observations. This research will drive further development of wave-current coupling in a modeling system that is freely available to the scientific community. The insight into wave-current interaction processes gained during this investigation will improve the development of realistic models used in practical sediment transport applications.

Most studies of inner-shelf circulation have focused on the role of wind stress. Surface waves have only recently been recognized as an important forcing mechanism over the inner shelf. Present understanding of the wave-driven inner-shelf circulation is based on analytical models with restrictive assumptions, such as constant turbulent mixing throughout the water column, and no spatial variations across the shelf. The model experiments in this study will allow for more realistic representations of turbulent mixing, and will include the effects of stratification, a sloping bottom and advection of momentum from the surf zone, where breaking waves generate strong along-shelf currents. Few previous studies have quantified the importance of momentum advection on the inner shelf, but it is potentially important near the boundary of the surf zone and will also be assessed in observations. Based on the model experiments, the relative importance of the hypothesized mechanisms under different environmental conditions will be scaled so that results can be applied generally at many locations.

The goal of this study is to identify the key processes that determine the observed spatial structure of the circulation driven by surface waves on the inner shelf, which is located offshore of the breaking surf. Previous observations have identified a surface-intensified offshore flow associated with surface waves over the inner shelf. In the direction parallel to shore, new observational analysis shows a complex response to wave forcing that varies with water depth. Two alternative hypotheses are formulated to account for these observations: one in which the Earth's rotation is necessary, and another that involves strong turbulent mixing and transport of momentum from the surf zone. Numerical modeling experiments, with complex physics but idealized geometry, will be carried out to determine the relative contribution of these two mechanisms to the observed wave-driven circulation during different forcing and environmental conditions. A new parameterization for the critical process of "wave streaming" near the bottom will be tested against field and laboratory observations. Model experiments, in combination with new analysis of existing observations, will identify processes that generate exchange between the surf zone and inner shelf during combined wind and wave forcing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this study is to identify the role of surface waves in driving circulation over the inner continental shelf, which is located offshore of the breaking surf. Exchange of water across the inner shelf influences the distribution of nutrients, harmful algal blooms, pollutants, larvae and sediment. Shoaling waves over the inner shelf affect transport of water through a process known as Stokes drift, which drives a net movement of water towards shore that is not measured by fixed instruments. Previous observational studies on the inner shelf have primarily addressed the role of wind forcing. Models that incorporate the effects of waves have been tested the surf zone where waves break but have been applied less often over the inner shelf.

This study used a two-fold approach to gain new understanding of the effects of surface waves over the inner shelf. First, existing long-term data sets of ocean currents and waves over the inner shelf were analyzed to compare the relative strength of different forces on water movement. A force balance is a framework that is often used to compare the strength of different physical processes that affect movement of water towards and away from shore.  In this study, observations of currents and wave-induced Stokes drift were combined to estimate a nonlinear component of the force balance that is often neglected.  The results from two different sites show that this component of the force balance can be substantial, especially during summer months when warming of the ocean surface creates a strong temperature contrast from the surface to the bottom. 

This analysis of long-term observations is complemented by model studies that include the complex physics of surface waves, but under idealized scenarios that simplify the variability of wind and waves, as well the complex shape of the coastline. Models that include a strong temperature contrast from the surface to the bottom give results that are consistent with results of the long-term observational analysis.  In addition, new formulations of a process known as wave-induced bottom streaming have now been implemented in a commonly-used modeling system. Results show that patterns of circulation and temperature are sensitive to how this process is represented, particularly just offshore of the breaking waves in the surf zone and during times when the waves have relatively long periods. This situation is common when remote storms create waves far away from the coastline on the U.S. west coast. 

In addition to surface waves, many studies of inner shelf circulation neglect differences in currents and temperature along different parts of the coastline. This includes the observational and modeling approaches described above. To address this issue, results from a recent set of detailed fiber-optic temperature measurements along the seafloor were analyzed at one of the observational sites on the New England inner shelf. These results show dramatic variability over short distances along the coast associated with sharp temperature fronts, a process that will need to be incorporated in future studies of inner shelf circulation.

In addition to understanding the physics of water movement due to the effects of wind and waves over the inner shelf, this study set out to relate these processes to variability of nearshore phytoplankton over the inner shelf. Phytoplankton form the base of the marine food web, but toxic harmful algal blooms can also have adverse impacts on coastal regions. Using data from collaborators in the Central and Northern California Ocean Observing System, physical factors influencing nearshore chlorophyll-a (an indicator of phytoplankton biomass) have been compared at two sites in the central California Current System. At the southern Monterey Bay site, which is relatively sheltered, high chlorophyll-a events tend to occur during periods of wind relaxation and low waves. This has implications for research on modeling and prediction of harmful algal blooms in this region. At the Bodega Bay site, which is less sheltered, observed chlorophyll-a events tend to be associated with increases in northwesterly winds, as well as surface Stokes drift. This is consistent with a previously hypothesized mechanism in which Stokes drift retains and concentrates phytoplankton near shore. The effects of Stokes drift were included in software that can track the origins of phytoplankton blooms using maps of surface currents from high frequency radar observations. Idealized models were also created for the situation of combined wind and waves typical for this site. The model results are consistent with an important role of wave-induced Stokes drift on transport of phytoplankton near the surface. In addition to the broader impacts on other disciplines, this research on nearshore chlorophyll-a variability has largely been carried out by graduate students who have gained valuable skills in data analysis and scientific research.
